reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
NOTE:Also see my:
Half-Life (1) Review
Half-Life 2 Review
Half-Life: Opposing Force Review
Black Mesa Review

INTRODUCTION:Half-Life: Blue Shift is a first-person action game by Gearbox Software and Valve and serves as the third official expansion to the Half-Life franchise.  Unlike Half-Life or Half-Life: Opposing Force, Blue Shift does not introduce new game mechanics; rather, it offers a new type of narrative storytelling through constant interactions with an NPC character (i.e., Dr. Rosenberg).

In this game, you step into the shoes of Black Mesa Security Guard and Clone Template Barney Calhoun, a man whose normal routine of offering beers and guarding doors is shattered with a catastrophic accident that opens the facility to an alien invasion and U.S. Military intervention (a direct result of Dr. Freeman's experiment from the first game).  As Barney Calhoun, you try to survive the alien invasion, protect the survivors, and escape the now doomed Black Mesa Research Facility.

PROS:+ Good story (NO SPOILERS) that serves as the 'final link' that connects every story (Half-Life, Half-Life: Opposing Force and Half-Life: Decay) of the Black Mesa Incident together.
+ Constant interaction with an NPC that is essential to the plot rather than for opening doors
+ The first game in the franchise to introduce 'HD' content during its time
+ Intense action as can be expected from a Half-Life game
+ Satisfying puzzles
+ Adaptive enemy AI, especially with the soldiers
+ Great level design
+ Barney can kill dangerous aliens and highly trained military soldiers wearing only a flak vest and an almost transparent plastic helmet as protection (He would be perfect in the Warhammer 40,000 universe as an Imperial Guardsman).

CONS:- VERY SHORT and possibly the shortest game I ever played with only 3 hours of playtime on Hard Mode and Training Tutorial
- Existence of bugs despite being 14 years old (Particularly a bug where you're unable to move)
- No new weapons, enemy, or gameplay mechanics.
- Most weapons from the first game were removed
- Relatively easy (even on hard mode) as compared to the other games.  In my opinion, it is because acquiring 'armor' and health kits are a lot easier.

CONCLUSION:Story and lore wise, Blue Shift is GOOD but other than that, it does not offer any new content aside from the new player perspective of the overall Half-Life Lore.  In my opinion, Blue Shift is not an expansion but more of a DLC (downloadable content) than anything else, which is not a bad thing by the way, especially one with a good story and fun action sequences.

So do you buy Blue Shift?  YES but DO NOT BUY Blue Shift alone! Instead, purchase Half-Life Anthology if you already have Half-Life 2 or get Half-Life Complete.

reviewText:
Half Life 1 was a fantastic first person shooting game released somewhere around 1999. This Blue Shift is the second rather dull expansion pack for Half Life 1. To be blunt, the first expansion Opposing Force is better, because it offers more guns, new gameplay mechanics and a lot of new monsters. Blue Shift however offers nothing new except new levels that will take you under 4 hours to complete the first time around.

Blue Shift takes you through Black Mesa and Xen once again when everything goes wrong and aliens invade. You start the expansion riding the tram to work (just like Half Life 1) after taking an optional training course that is literally the same training course from Half Life 1.

The gameplay is more challenging than the original game in both good and bad ways. The good way is the game shows off its artificial intelligence by pitting you... Barney Calhoun, a blue shift security guard at Black Mesa, against hundreds of marines sent into the Black Mesa facility. Usually you fight 10 marines at a time in wide open areas. The enemies will scatter when you throw grenades, run away from you, try to flank you and fan out so you're not shooting enemies like dominoes.

The negative ways that the expansion is challenging comes from several dark areas with dozens of head crabs jumping at you around every turn. It feels cheap compared to Half Life 1 and Opposing Force.

There are a few shining lights for this expansion and that is rescuing scientists, although it's not much of a rescue, because any of them can die and it doesn't matter. The expansion also dabbles in having an important character Dr. Rosenburg that you will rescue and he will guide you to the end of the expansion. Guide you as in briefly tell you what to do through believable voice acting.

In all this is a lackluster expansion compared to the previous one and feels more like a level pack... without levels, just one continuous game. Chances are you can get this expansion with one of the deluxe Half Life 1 games, so save some money and get Blue Shift there instead.

reviewText:
Half-Life: Blue Shift... I REALLY want to go in-depth with this game, people... but it's just too short to say much about it... so... I'll try...

Blue Shift is another expansion pack for Half-Life 1. Much like it's predecassor, you take the view of Barney Calhoun, a security officer working in Black Mesa and a personal friend to Gordon Freeman. Here's the thing that probably many people wondered in their Christmas of 2001. Opening the game up from the box, popping it into their brand-new Windows XP computer, and watching the opening sequence, and noticing something different... the outstanding graphics for the time. Seriously, as far as I know, this game is only famous for two things, Barney appearing as a major character in Half-Life 2, 3 years later, and the graphics in this game for 2001, as Opposed, *ahem*, opposed to Opposing Force and the original Half-Life. If you had essentially the i7 type of computer of back then, and were one of the cool kids already with a GameCube, PS2, and original Xbox in your possesion, you were amazed with the visuals of Blue Shift. But, I'm sorry to say... that's really is almost the only reason this game is... well... was known. The story is about as basic as it can get.

Barney Calhoun is doing duty as a security officer in the Black Mesa Research Facility and going down an elevator when, shock, the facility experiences a Resonance Cascade caused by Gordon Freeman submitting a Xen(ian) crystal in a test chamber for analysis, causing confused alien species to enter Black Mesa and vaporise all the remaining employees at every turn (satisfying) and your goal is to, you guessed it, escape the facility with the few surviving scientists guiding your way to a possible exit, while killing all the aliens that you can kill. Eventually, though, Barney is able to teleport himself at the surface of the facility, along with Dr. Rosenberg,  shortly after witnessing a montage of the events Gordon Freeman faced. He supposedly drives away along with a few scientists in an SUV to safety, away from Black Mesa.

Pros: Graphics and animations were innovative for the time. The game also served as the basis for Barney's purpose in the next Half-Life game, Half-Life 2, and did it fairly well.

Cons: Game felt EXTREMELY short and, personally, I just didn't find Dr. Rosenberg very interesting. Only took me about 2 hours to beat, and 4 more just to TRY Hard difficulty and to see if it made a difference, but just felt like the first Half-Life game on Normal. Speaking of which... the Easy mode of Half-Life: Blue Shift is just about the most boring excuse of a Half-Life game I've ever seen. I'm sorry, but I don't find the constant, constant, CONSTANT health packs, ammo, suit health, and health machines ALL over the friggin place to be like a Half-Life game. To be honest, HARD mode seems to have this down... it makes the health packs, etc. give you LESS health, suit health, etc. But in Easy mode... I think I had a harder time playing the 2nd stage of Portal 1. Also... no G-Man.

Overall, it's a passable Half-Life game. It still has the dark humor as the other titles, and the story, while short, still felt like a good distraction from time to time. Only play Blue Shift if you're EXTRA curious about the story of Barney Calhoun. Wanna know how short the game is? Writing this review took longer than the game itself, lol.

7.0/10

reviewText:
Blue Shift is another continuation of the original Half Life games. This time you assume the role of security guard Barney Calhoun, during the events of the original game. Just like the original game and Opposing Force, your main objective is to survive by assisting fellow Black Mesa Employees, using any weapon or tool to your advantage and by using your wits. Blue shift does just that.

Gameplay wise, It's still the engaging Half Life everyone knows and loves. Real Time cutscenes? Check. Aggresive and sophisticated enemies? Check. Reliable friendly NPC's? Check. Clever puzzles and well designed levels? Check. And the epic and intense gunplay that the original had? Yep, it's all here. Graphically, it's just like the previous games. The levels look as varied as ever, and the audio still breaths a great atmosphere into the game. So far, everything that is included in this expansion is good.

But it's the worst installment in the series.

And why, do you ask? Because, unlike it's predecessors, it's really short. Really, really short. And unlike Opposing Force, it didn't really add anything new. OK, maybe the HEV battery pickups have now been replaced by Body armour since you are a security guard instead of a heavily armoured scientist/soldier. But... other than that... that's it. No new guns, no new NPC types, friendly or enemy, no new level obstacles and gimmicks, no nothing. Hell, it even lacks some things from the original Half Life, such as certain weapons and an end boss. With an impressive expansion like Opposing force being released before this, I was honestly expecting to see a lot more, but instead, it feels like a watered down Half Life. It's still nice, but it could've been so much more.

Overall, Half Life: Blue Shift is a fairly decent expansion, although a tad bit underwhelming considering the content it's two predecessors delivered before it. If you enjoyed Half Life or Opposing Force, I'd say you check Blue Shift out. If you never played either of those two, this is not the best place to start. It's way too short and light on content and the other Half Life games deliver so much more. Get those instead, then buy this during a sale.

reviewText:
If you haven't played Half Life or Half Life Opposing Force (which is an expansion to Half Life), then here's the gist.  You play as Barney the Security Officer.  He makes a few cameos in the first game (and in Half Life 2 is a major role).  Opposing Force has you playing a soldier from the US military doing missions during the play of the Half Life game.  Blue Shift is the same.  In Half Life, Opposing Force, and Blue Shift you are all playing in the same time period, just different roles.

Now for the game itself.  It is short.  It isn't crap, though.  It is quite well done, and shows a bit of the inner workings of the Black Mesa compound.  If you haven't played Half Life 1 then you might be confused on what exactly is going on, but if you're just looking to play a short singleplayer FPS, then this is something to hold you over.

I bought it back when it was around 10-20 bucks.  I don't know the price of it now, but I wouldn't pay more than 5 dollars.  If it's not 5, then wait for a sale.  It really isn't worth more.  The only reason it isn't worth more is that you can complete it in 2-3 hours, maybe even less.  But the gameplay is still fun and interesting and has the original Half Life touch to it.

reviewText:
Pros
-Still looks and feels like a Half-Life game/story.
-You finally find out which random security guard is Barney Calhoun. And it would seem that it was none of the Half-Life guards!
-Overloaded with easter eggs, especially near the beginning.
-HEV chargers are still operational despite the fact that you can't use them. I just found that amusing.

Cons
-Has some really outlandish puzzles, even more-so than certain Valve puzzles could be. How was I supposed to know that pushing a barrel over two broken wires equals MAKING THE DYNAMITE EXPLODE?
-Easily the shortest entry in the Half-Life series, even shorter than Half-Life 2: Episode 1 (and I play games at a snail's pace).
-Not much new content in general when compared to Opposing Force. No new weapons, enemies, etc. I mean, there's a new character, so I guess that's something...
-The closest you get to a final boss is making sure the teleporter doesn't explode or whatever.
-There's a REALLY annoying bug where, if you die and respawn by clicking one of the mouse buttons, your weapon will constantly fire off until you click the mouse button again. I'm not sure if there's a fix for this or even if it's just me, but just be wary of that.

Conclusion
Out of all of the entries in the Half-Life franchise, this is probably the least impactful. In fact, I'm willing to bet there have been mods for Half-Life that both continue the story in its own way and left more of an impact to the player. That being said though, this expansion isn't bad by any means. Just not quite as good as other games in the series.

If you want this game, I'd recommend buying one of the Half-Life complete packs if you don't have a large number of the other entries. You'll get the other entries and save money overall in the process.

Half-Life: Blue Shift

Short but sweet


After the success of Opposing Force, Gearbox decided to make another expansion pack for Valves critically acclaimed fps, Half-Life.

When aliens from Xen are teleported to his work place at Black Mesa, security guard Barney Calhoun must cut his shift short and try to escape the alien infested base, as well as fighting off the HECU marines who are tasked with neutralising the situation by killing all lifeforms in the facility.

Like Half-Life, the game explains where you need to go, what you need to do and why, however trying to wrap your head around the backstory of the Half-Life universe proves to be a difficult task. This expansion pack brings us to new areas of Black Mesa, unseen in previous games and there are a few Gordon Freeman cameos throughout.

What made Opposing Forces‚Äô gameplay so much fun and memorable was the fact that Gearbox introduced new weapons and enemies. Unfortunately, in Blue Shift, all the weapons and enemies were recycled from Half-Life. Dr Rosenberg‚Äôs companionship was a new gameplay aspect introduced in Blue shift. Unlike other scientist in Half-Life, who only have 4 character models, Dr Rosenberg has distinctive facial features and is an essential character who makes multiple appearances throughout the game. As well as this new feature, you can look forward to the return of fun but difficult puzzles and awesome shootouts against aliens and soldiers.

Like Opposing Force, the graphics in this game have dated significantly since 2001. It is still enjoyable none the less however for those gamers who play the new shiny 1080p games, then this may be a struggle for you. Like all Half-Life games, a lot of thought has gone into the level design especially in the old areas of Black Mesa, where the equipment, hallways and signs have new textures. After the success of Opposing Force, Gearbox decided to make another expansion pack for Valves critically acclaimed fps, Half-Life.

When aliens from Xen are teleported to his work place at Black Mesa, security guard Barney Calhoun must cut his shift short and try to escape the alien infested base, as well as fighting off the HECU marines who are tasked with neutralising the situation by killing all lifeforms in the facility.

Like Half-Life, the game explains where you need to go, what you need to do and why, however trying to wrap your head around the backstory of the Half-Life universe proves to be a difficult task. This expansion pack brings us to new areas of Black Mesa, unseen in previous games and there are a few Gordon Freeman cameos throughout.

What made Opposing Forces‚Äô gameplay so much fun and memorable was the fact that Gearbox introduced new weapons and enemies. Unfortunately, in Blue Shift, all the weapons and enemies were recycled from Half-Life. Dr Rosenberg‚Äôs companionship was a new gameplay aspect introduced in Blue shift. Unlike other scientist in Half-Life, who only have 4 character models, Dr Rosenberg has distinctive facial features and is an essential character who makes multiple appearances throughout the game. As well as this new feature, you can look forward to the return of fun but difficult puzzles and awesome shootouts against aliens and soldiers.

reviewText: Half Life: Blue Shift is an expansion of the first Half Life where we play as a security guard and we relive the Black Mesa incident through his eyes but will you want to play it ? In Half Life: Blue Shift we play as Barney Calhoun who works as a security guard  at Black Mesa. The alien and soldier attack happens and we need to escape. So how is Half Life: Blue Shift ? Well I wish there was a mediocre button cause this game ain't bad, but it isn't good either. Compared to Opposing Force this adds nothing to the original game. No new weapons, horrible level design and incredibly short. This expansion  is really nothing special and it pains me to say that. The gameplay isn't even fun this time as this time it revolves around jumping puzzles and not so much around gun fights. This expansion is also really easy compared to Half Life as there is no threat standing in your way. The game is still fun enough for you to finish it but it is very disappointing. Overall there is not much to say about Half Life: Blue Shift. It's not a bad game but it's not good compared to Opposing Force and Half Life. If you want to finish the entire series than by all means pick it up, but if not than wait for a sale or skip this entirely.  I give Half Life: Blue Shift a 6/10

Well this was underwhelming. I'll vote the game down. Why? Because if one buys the Anthology, he won't care about this at all. But if someone checks the individual games, maybe gets a little look into the game, and I hope that can understand this. To be really short: game is too short, quite shallow, less guns, less varied environments - nowhere as good as HL or Opposing Forces.

HL Blue Shift currently stands at 90% positive reviews, while HL and Opposing Forces if I remember well has 96% and 95%  positives, and I have to agree with the trend - the game was fine, but not even as good as HL (This is my third, final review of the anthology - in my book Opposing Forces > Half-Life > Blue Shift, simply based amount the fun I had while playing)
The game features a really awesome physics based puzzle (barrels in coolant), had a fun part shooting gas cannisters' top to make them shoot at a door, and a barrel-detonator puzzle  which is really questionable in my opinion.
Otherwise this game feels like a well-written, longer trailer for Half-Life. Alien contact's majority are headcrabs, there are maybe two Alien Grunts and Masters - the enemy variety could have been better from the gameplay aspect - the lack of stronger enemies really felt like the protagonist is away from the bigger happenings, making him feel like an underdog.
The gametime is about 3-4 hours, and the highs of it are the various little physics puzzles,  but other than that this game is everything but memorable.  We have less weapons than in the base game - Glock, Colt, machine gun, shotgun, rocket launcher, granade and satchel charge. (Plus Snarks, based on wiki) It's about the half of the arsenal we had in the base game or in Opposing Forces - this, with the short campaign makes this game nowhere as fun as the other titles were.

reviewText:
THe Second official Expansion to Half-Life and in my opinion the better. While it is actually smaller, both in scope and features the scope makes sense. You play as Barney Calhoun, a member of the Blue shift ..i.e the security force of Black mesa. Yup That's you.

The events run parallel to to the story of Half Life and Opposing FOrce though Mr. Calhoun has the distinction of the three which you might already be able to guess at.

The Good:

* Well Done Areas
* Short Play Time
* High CHallenge

YOu'd think SHort Playtime would be a bad thing but honestly it works to the advantage of the game. Much like Portal it's juuus long enough to be fun but not so long that the areas start to drag on or feel padded. The challenge is ramped up due to the simple fact that barney has limited armor... no HEV, PCV charging or energy packs for you... just whatever you can strip off the corpses of your comrades. It adds a layer of tension.

The Bad:

* Fewer Weapons

This is about the only con and it makes sense.Barney is conf9ned to the more mundane weaponry.... but again this feels right.

All in all a great addition that does better than opposing force at expanding. opposing Force while good suffered from trying too hard .. Blue Shift is confident enought in what it offers that it doesn't need to throw much in.

reviewText:
If you liked the original Half Life, you will probably like this too. It's essentially the same, aside from showing the origin of Valve (so many valves you need to turn).

This time the story is told from a guard's POV. Man, if only the other guards were as useful as Calhoun, the first Half Life would have been so much better!  Just like Freeman, Calhoun started his ordinary day at his job, until the incident happened. Being that Calhoun was a guard and experienced shooter, Blue Shift is more believeable than the original Half Life where a scientist becomes Rambo.

Gameplay and visuals are the same since it's using the same engine. Unlike Half Life, it wasn't too heavy on the platforming, but that's probably because the game is really short. While I wasn't trying to break Half LIfe, I never encountered any problems with enemy AI. In Blue Shift, enemy AI was really terrible at times. At one point where you're locked in a truck with the scientist, they kept throwing grenades at the locked door and killed themselves. Another time I flanked them and they just froze and didn't register me at all after shooting them. Guess it isn't as polished as Half Life.

NPCs are once again a chore. When I was escorting the scientist to the lab, he kept stopping and complaining that he's tired. The first time he did that was back in the truck. He didn't even leave the truck and he complained about beeing exhausted.

Overall, the game was too short to stand out too much, and most of the gameplay was too similar to Half Life. It was still fun playing it and a nice touch, getting to play as one of the guards. From what I hear, this event gets completely ignored in Half Life 2, but can't complain about that, as nothing much happened story wise in this expansion. 6/10

reviewText:
Whereas Opposing Force was Half-Life if Gordon never went to Xen, Blue Shift is just a rerun of the first few levels of HL1. There's no new weapons (even less than HL1 for that matter), very few, if any, memorable set pieces, a handful of easy puzzles, lazy enemy encounters, and the whole experience in general just feels like it's going through the motions.

It feels as if it was incomplete, not just because it's incredibly short either, but also because there's no real climax throughout the entire campaign! While Opposing Force was shorter than Half-Life, the tension was constantly rising until it was noticeably more difficult than HL1 ever became. Furthermore, OF introduced many new weapons and (somewhat finnicky) mechanics! You'd think if Blue Shift had nothing new to offer, they'd at least grab everything that made the original so great and go out with a bang, but sadly instead it goes out with a whimper.

Shame really, the High Definition patch (circa 2000 standards) is nifty, but I can't say I would recommend going back and playing this one.

reviewText:
Blue Shift an expansion to the Half-Life franchise but as with any expansion to Half-Life it feels a little underwhelming when held up against the multitude of magnificent mods available for free.

Blue Shift casts you as the security guard Barney, letting Gorden Freeman have some quiet time until Half-Life 2 is released and sends you on your marry way through alien monstrosities and overzealous government soldiers. It plays much the same as the original, the weapons and enemies remain unchanged and the maps will feel eerily familiar as you battle through the corridors of Black Mesa.

The game just doesn't do anything new, it's feels almost like a recycled game, like you did all this before only it was fun the first time around. Thankfully the game is extremely short so your pain won't last long and you can safely uninstall this and go back the playing the various superior mods for Half-Life, both single- and multi-player.

Perhaps the only redeeming quality is the high definition models pack that comes bundled with Blue Shift that gives the game a little a extra. However it should be noted that Half-Life can look much prettier than even that, you just have to play maps and mods that weren't made by Valve.

Half-Life: Blue Shift.  I wish there was such a thing as a Blue Shift in the real world of work, seeing as a Blue Shift at Black Mesa only lasts 3 hours.  Now Half-Life and Half-Life: Opposing Force are not known for their lengthly storylines but one would come to expect a little more from an expansion to one of the greatest games of all time.

Blue Shift places the player in the shoes of Black Mesa security officer Barney as he attempts to escape the Black Mesa science facility during the events of the original Half-Life; which run in parallel with the Blue Shift storyline.  Unfortunately the very limited script and lack of anything that could be considered an expansion of the original Half-Life experience means you will feel rather unsatisfied by the rather lacklustre ending to what feels like no more than a fan made mod.

The only reason I can recommend for playing Blue Shift is to that you are granted an additional 3 hours of Half-Life gameplay, which can only be a good thing.

I know that I'm going to be hated for this but I don't like this game. It's really not worth it. The game tries little to nothing new or interesting. The story is about one of the security guards of Black Mesa, Barney Calhoun. If you've played Half Life 2, you probably remember the opening where a combine soldier takes you to an enclosed room and reveals to Gordon Freeman that he is one of your best friends. Ok, but that raises the question. If Barney is friends with Gordon then how come you only see Gordon Freeman in Blue Shift once or twice?
The gameplay is exactly the same as the original Half-Life. The only difference is that you have fewer weapons than you did in Half-Life 1 and they're all typical weapons that you would find in virtually any FPS ever made and no interesting and or exotic weapons at all; assault rifle, shot gun, pistol, revolver, grenade, satchel charge, rocket launcher, and the  crowbar that was in the original Half-Life game. Oh, and let's not forget that you can't use HEV chargers to charge your armor and can make you take less damage, even though they're all over the game.
The enemies are the exact same ones as in the original Half-Life. There are no new ones at all.
There is a glitch in the game that made me pull every strand of hair out of my scalp. Right before the residence cascade from HL1, you have to enter an elevator with 2 scientists. Right before the residence cascade, the 2 scientists explode and you have to start over from the last checkpoint and you will go through that glitch again and again, until you start the entire game over.
Overrall, this game is not one of the worst game ever, it's just not worth buying. I guess the only redeemable part about this game is the HD pack, which improves the textures, character models, and switches some of the weapon designs to the models from the PS2 port.

Half Life, the story of man of science turned man of action Gordon Freeman as he is trapped in the Black Mesa research facility during the Resonance Cascade, an event in which aliens from the borderworld Xen begin flooding the complex and killing everyone inside; and Gordon has two major goals: Stop the alien invasion before it begins, and come back in one piece.

But Gordon wasn't the only one there that day with an unbreakable will to live. Blue Shift follows Barney Calhoun, a mere security guard in the Black Mesa facility; and his only goal is to escape, but between aliens killing everyone and HECU soldiers trying to cover up the incident(also by killing everyone), that's not an easy goal.

Everyone will tell you that Opposing Force is the better Half Life expansion, but it's not in my opinion. Me, I prefer lore based games rather than challenge based games, and that's what Blue Shift is. While everone says Opossing Force is better because it has new enemies and weapons, it follows an HECU soldier, which in Half Life are enemies. It's nice to see a different side of the soldiers, and find that maybe they're not all ruthless killers, but it's harder to care about them after having killed dozens of them in Half Life.

Oh well. After Playing through Blue Shift on Hard difficulty I have to say that I can understand the criticism this game got. But after all it was a really good ... little campaign. I think the points of criticism (no new Weapons, no Endboss, no new Enemies etc.) are valid considering the original Half Life and its quality. But surprisingly enough these points seemed very fiiting to me. I mean after all we arent the Hero of the story. We are nothing special at all. We are just a security officer that tries to get the hell out of the catastrophy he got into. Why should he use some super new Weapons ? He uses what he can find. Why should he beat a giant Alien or Endboss ? He is simply trying to get away, not trying to save the world (like Rosenberg pointed out during the Elevator Scene). Other than that I have to say that I found the atmosphere to be really amazing. I felt so much like a confused lonely surviver trying to stay alive running for his life. All these dark coridors and the environment crumbling away. Electricity shooting out of walls and stuff like that. The biggest personal point of criticism for me is that it only took me 4 hours to complete the campaign on the hardest difficulty. Ultimately, if you enjoy the Half Life Universe I can only recommend you to play it. Its short, its atmospheric, its intense.\n\n- Pudels

Half-Life: Blue Shift is the second and final expansion for the original Half-Life and was developed by Gearbox Software (the same developers for the first expansion Opposing Force) and published by Valve. A fairly short but decent expansion which gives us yet another perspective to the entire Black Mesa Incident from a different character.

This time the player takes on the role of Barney Calhoun, a security officer employed at the Black Mesa Research Facility and the man who has helped Gordon Freeman out of so many sticky and difficult situations. The game starts out with Barney Calhoun carrying out his duties and then being caught up in the Black Mesa Incident which, like Opposing Force, cleverly coincides with the original Half-Life‚Äôs storyline.

What Gearbox Software does well is maintaining the atmosphere and world of the original Half-Life while providing the experience through the eyes of someone else who was involved in the story of the original Half-Life. For me, Blue Shift felt like the final game in the Penumbra series (Penumbra: Requiem) as it ends the first Half-Life game‚Äôs storyline in a fairly chilled and relaxing way without forcing the player to battle an end boss whilst providing a few situations where a puzzle needs to be solved.

The core gameplay is the same as it is for Half-Life and Opposing Force with the weapons and other items not really changing which isn‚Äôt necessarily a bad thing. The health system is also the same with some slight changes as those that were in Opposing Force. Since security officers do not wear HEV suits, they cannot make use of any HEV suit charger units that are located around the facility. Instead the player must pick up security officer issued body armour vests and helmets to replenish their armour protection. Something that I‚Äôve noticed about Blue Shift is that you will find an enormous amount of first aid packs around each chapter and this makes the game less challenging. The player‚Äôs flashlight seems to have been designed differently with the way light is dispersed in dark places which felt a lot more realistic.

Structurally, the game is chaptered like the previous games and provides a fun, linear storyline that will keep you engaged and wanting to find out more. Barney Calhoun does not encounter any of the alien creatures of Race X as Adrian Shepherd did in Opposing Force, but does encounter hostility from the marines and the traditional Xen alien creatures.

Overall, there is not much more that could be said about Half-Life: Blue Shift. It provides a new and interesting perspective to the storyline which leaves a lot of questions and few answers. For those who want to return to the events of the Black Mesa Incident and see the situation unfold from a different viewpoint then I highly recommend Blue Shift. I personally found it a joy to play and think it is just as good as Opposing Force.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion for the critically acclaimed Half-Life. In blue shift, you play as the security guard Barney Calhoun, who was present is the vanilla Half-Life, and the next games in the series. You're paying for more Half-Life, and that's what you're getting. Blue Shift is kinda fun, but not neccesary to play in order to fully understand the story of the following games.

Tl;dr:

If you loved Half:Life and are craving for more gameplay that is very similar, buy it. If you're playing it for more story, progression of the main characters or variety in the set-in-stone Half-Life gameplay, Blue-Shift will dissapoint.
